comments.body: Will we ever omit the port? I think we have to include it all the time?
I guess we can omit it if its 80?
Won't it always be https? so 443 :) But yeah, I guess it's not a big deal.
To help clients reach servers in the most network-efficient way possible, a map of client CIDR to a server address believed reachable and ideal from that CIDR.
This leaks internal go type names into our API. @bgrant0607

> This leaks internal go type names into our API. @bgrant0607

`kind` isn't necessarily the same as the go type name.  This is `kind` in the `RESTMapper` sense that uses the `kind` in the JSON serialization.  Or at least that was the intent.
As mentioned in the issue, `kind` is already part of the API.
I'm just about certain that we'll end up needing the full Group,Version,Kind to properly support something like Scale.  Do you want to nest this into a prettier structure?
API resource is served under a specific GroupVersion (e.g. `/apis/company.com/v1`) so it seems redundant.

> API resource is served under a specific GroupVersion (e.g. /apis/company.com/v1) so it seems redundant.

Consider `replicationcontrollers/scale`.  In the end it should live in the "" group, but accept a kind from the "extensions" group.  Its a general problem we have with that sort of endpoint, since something like the HPA controller should be able to scale anything in any group.

As far as I know there is no affordance (currently) for serving APIResource objects for subresources.  If we wanted to do that we'd probably need to have a full sub-object here anyway, seems beyond the scope of this PR.
Subresources need to be handled differently.

`kind` is definitely needed in order to support non-hardcoded discovery from kubectl. 

We'll also need a list of subresources, such as scale, supported by the resource, but that doesn't need to be added by this PR.

cc @lavalamp
@lavalamp, this actually is an API change. [edit] Let me know if it's appropriate.

Right, it's totally fine to add this status code to the api. The thing I was talking about was the range of codes we could possibly return from a given request. I don't think we consider that part of the API, or at least it's not written down places. I could be wrong?

Hmm..The status code that will be sent by the server is listed In the api-converions doc, and 410 is not there. https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/api-conventions.md#http-status-codes. Does that make the status code part of the API?

Good catch. Please include a change to that doc in this PR!
